item.title: Victims in Istanbul Airport Attack Reflect City’s International Character
item.description: Hours after the bombings, a limited number of flights resumed and workers continued clearing debris and replacing shattered windows at the airport.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO, SABRINA TAVERNISE and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Boris Johnson Won’t Seek to Lead Britain, but Michael Gove Will
item.media:description: Michael Gove, who is seeking to succeed David Cameron as prime minister of Britain, said that Mr. Johnson “cannot provide the leadership or build the team for the task ahead.”
item.description: Mr. Johnson’s decision not to seek leadership of the Conservative Party followed the decision of an ally, Mr. Gove, to enter the contest.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Turkey, a Conduit for Fighters Joining ISIS, Begins to Feel Its Wrath
item.media:description: Relatives of suicide bombing victim Mohammad Eymen Demirci at his funeral on Wednesday in Istanbul. The Turkish government and Western officials said the suicide bombings at Istanbul’s main airport on Tuesday bore the hallmarks of an Islamic State attack.
item.description: For years, Turkey served as a rear base, transit hub and shopping bazaar for the Islamic State, but now, officials say Tuesday’s attack bore ISIS hallmarks.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: The E.U. Is Democratic. It Just Doesn’t Feel That Way.
item.media:description: From left, standing, President François Hollande of France, Prime Minister Charles Michel of Belgium and Prime Minister Xavier Bettel of Luxembourg at a European Union summit meeting in Brussels on Wednesday. Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, right, and Prime Minister Beata Szydlo of Poland are in the foreground.
item.description: The bloc was designed to rise above and defuse nationalist politics. That is why, for many Europeans, it does not feel like a functioning democracy.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: With Both Parties in Turmoil, Britain Weighs a General Election
item.media:description: The Labour Party leader, Jeremy Corbyn, speaking at a rally on Wednesday in London.
item.description: A successor to Prime Minister David Cameron might want to seek his or her own mandate from voters after the decision to exit the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: 9 in Navy Disciplined Over Iran’s Capture of Sailors
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Revolutionary Guards in January showed detained American sailors at an undisclosed site in Iran.
item.media:credit: Sepahnews, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A review of the incident, which occurred in January when two 50-foot Navy boats strayed into the waters near Farsi Island, found widespread mistakes.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Palestinian, 19, Stabs 13-Year-Old to Death in West Bank Settlement
item.media:description: Soldiers outside a house in the West Bank settlement of Kiryat Arba, where a 13-year-old girl was fatally stabbed on Thursday.
item.description: The attack in the Kiryat Arba settlement was the latest in a series that began eight months ago; the assailant was shot and killed.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and MYRA NOVECK

item.title: A Slow, Steady Siege on an ISIS Stronghold in Libya
item.media:description: Fighters loyal to the United Nations-backed unity government fighting Islamic State snipers last week in western Surt, Libya.
item.description: With a willing commander, a Times correspondent and photographer set off down a highway strewn with the charred remains of vehicles destroyed in suicide bombings.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Kenyan Filed a Complaint Against the Police, Then He and His Lawyer Disappeared
item.media:description: Dozens of lawyers stood on the steps of Kenya’s Supreme Court on Wednesday to call on the government to immediately open an independent investigation into why a lawyer, his client in a case against a police officer and a taxi driver disappeared last week.
item.description: After leaving court and climbing into a taxi last week, the pair and their driver vanished, alarming Kenya’s human rights community and roping in Western embassies.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: U.S. Criticizes Myanmar Over Human Trafficking
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and and Secretary of State John Kerry in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, in May.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nyein Chan Naing
item.description: In an annual report, the State Department lumped the fledgling democracy together with Iran, North Korea and Syria.
item.dc:creator: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN

item.title: Taiwan-Owned Steel Factory Caused Toxic Spill, Vietnam Says
item.media:description: Mai Tien Dung, right, minister chairman of the government office, said Vietnam would seek $500 million in compensation from the Formosa Ha Tinh Steel Corporation for the chemical spill.
item.description: The government is seeking $500 million in compensation from Formosa Ha Tinh Steel for the spill that killed marine life and sickened many people.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Taliban Attack on Convoy of Afghan Police Cadets Kills at Least 27
item.description: The bombings were the second large-scale assault by the militants in Kabul in less than two weeks.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MOHAMAD FAHIM ABED

item.title: Refugees Encounter a Foreign Word: Welcome
item.description: How Canadian hockey moms, poker buddies and neighbors are adopting Syrians, a family at a time.
item.dc:creator: JODI KANTOR and CATRIN EINHORN

item.title: Extradition of ‘El Chapo’ to U.S. Is Halted in Mexico
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug kingpin known as El Chapo, in January.
item.description: Lawyers for the drug kingpin, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, who is also notorious for multiple escapes from jail, have filed several appeals.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Spanish Tax Authorities Investigate Google
item.media:description: Tax officials leaving Google’s offices in Madrid on Thursday.
item.description: Officials visited the technology giant’s offices in Madrid as part of their inquiry, broadening the scrutiny in Europe of how the company pays taxes.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Memo From London: To Remake Britain’s Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn Might Kill It
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour Party leader, at a rally for him in London on Wednesday.
item.description: For the Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, losing seats in Parliament appears to be acceptable collateral damage in his long-term bid to reshape the party.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sinosphere: Beijing Police Officers Arrested in Environmentalist’s Death
item.description: An autopsy found that Lei Yang had died of suffocation after the police seized him, and two officers have been charged with “dereliction of duty.”
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Turkey Says Airport Bombers Were From Kyrgyzstan, Russia and Uzbekistan
item.description: Officials have blamed the Islamic State for the attack in which dozens were killed, and raids and arrests have been carried out across the country.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Boris Johnson Isn’t Running; Jeremy Corbyn Seeks Labour Revolution
item.media:description: Michael Gove, the justice secretary and one of the leaders of the “Leave” campaign, is a candidate to replace David Cameron as leader of the Conservative Party.
item.description: The Conservative Party (and by extension, Britain) is moving toward a new leader, while many people still don’t seem to know what “Brexit” is.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: At Least 15 Killed in Suicide Bomb Attacks in North Cameroon
item.description: Authorities in northern Cameroon say at least 15 people have died and dozens are wounded after two suicide bombing attacks.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Roadside Attack Near Somali Capital Leaves at Least 14 Dead
item.media:description: The wreckage of a bus struck by a roadside bomb in Lafoole, near Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, on Thursday.
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but officials in the town of Lafoole said they believed the assault was the work of Islamist Shabab militants.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: Philippines’ New President, Rodrigo Duterte, Vows Tough Stance on Crime
item.description: He said in his inaugural speech that the harm of corruption and drugs justified his approach, and he dismissed concerns that such a campaign would abuse the rule of law.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Who Else Can Sponsor a Refugee? The List Is Limited, for Now
item.media:description: Liz Stark, the grandmother in chief of a sponsor group in Canada, which allows citizens to band together in small groups and personally resettle — essentially adopt — a refugee family.
item.description: Canada has a longstanding policy allowing private sponsorship, but other countries are starting to experiment. Here’s how.
item.dc:creator: JODI KANTOR and CATRIN EINHORN
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Beijing Rejects South China Sea Case Ahead of July 12 Ruling
item.media:description: People protesting territorial claims that Beijing has made in the South China Sea in front of the Chinese consular office in Makati City, south of Manila, in the Philippines, in June.
item.description: The case centers on an argument by the Philippines that China’s claims over much of the sea are illegal under a United Nations convention.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Father Killed in Turkey Attacks Was Trying to Save Son From ISIS
item.media:description: Fathi Bayoudh, a respected officer and doctor in the Tunisian military, who died in the attack on Istanbul’s main airport on Tuesday.
item.description: His son had called a month after reaching the Islamic State in Syria, asking for help and to return home.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 2 Groups Call to Oust Saudis from U.N. Human Rights Council
item.media:description: The northern city of Saada, Yemen, a Houthi rebel stronghold that has come under intense bombardment by the Saudi-led military coalition, in September 2015.
item.description: But the suspension of any country from an elected body of the United Nations is extraordinary, and it would be all the more so for a country with powerful friends like the United States.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Mining Companies Buy Political Influence in Australia, Report Says
item.media:description: Annastacia Palaszczuk, the premier of Queensland, Australia, earlier this month. A new report contends that donations from the mining industry bought access to Queensland state officials.
item.description: A report cited six instances where political donations were made and companies received favorable legislation for mining projects.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Trilobites: Don’t Get on the Wrong Side of This New Tarantula
item.media:description: The newly found tarantula, Kankuamo marquezi, uses its urticating hairs, or butt bristles, to maim potential attackers.
item.description: Kankuamo marquezi, a newly discovered member of the tarantula family, uses bristles on its rear end to attack foes.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Kim Jong-un Takes an Additional Title in North Korea
item.media:description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un was appointed as chairman of the newly created Commission on State Affairs on Tuesday.
item.description: In a bid to solidify his one-man rule, Kim Jong-un gained yet another leadership role — chairman of a new agency created by North Korea’s parliament.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere: ‘Brexit’ May Lead to Diminished British Voice on Hong Kong
item.media:description: People’s Liberation Army soldiers raising the Chinese flag in Hong Kong on July 1, 1997, during the ceremony marking the end of British colonial rule.
item.description: A shrunken economy and political isolation, possible outcomes if Britain withdraws from the E.U., could weaken London’s influence on Hong Kong affairs.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: How China Took Center Stage in Bitcoin’s Civil War
item.media:description: Racks of computers at a server farm mining Bitcoin and Ethereum.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Through vast server farms and canny investments, Chinese companies have effectively centralized control over a currency designed to be borderless.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: Norwegian Court Approves Extradition of Mullah Krekar, a Terror Suspect
item.media:description: Najmaddin Faraj Ahmad, commonly known as Mullah Krekar, in 2015.
item.description: The mullah, an Iraqi formally known as Najmuddin Faraj Ahmad, faces charges in Italy. He has been accused of leading a militant group.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Lawmakers Urge John Kerry to Press U.N. for Haiti Cholera Response
item.media:description: A Health Ministry worker was sprayed with a sanitizing solution after delivering the bodies of cholera victims to a mass grave outside Port-au-Prince, Haiti, in November 2010.
item.description: Angry over a six-year epidemic traced to United Nations peacekeepers, 158 members of Congress asked Mr. Kerry to push for a solution, including reparations.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Victim of Racist Taunts in England: A Mexican-American Who Backs ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Juan Jasso, the target of a racist tirade in Manchester, England, that was captured on video Tuesday and drew international attention on social media. Mr. Jasso is an American who teaches at a college in Manchester.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Juan Jasso, 38, said his views had not been changed by the xenophobic insults he endured on a tram in Manchester.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: The Interpreter: Turkey’s Twin Terrorist Threats, Explained
item.media:description: Shattered glass from Tuesday’s suicide bombings at Istanbul’s main airport. The Turkish government blamed the Islamic State for the attack.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Islamic State and Kurdish militant groups are themselves enemies, but their violence has become part of an overlapping set of problems rooted in Syria.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In Australian Election, Discontent Is the Front-Runner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia in Sydney on Wednesday with his wife, Lucy. His support has tumbled to 48 percent in June from a high of 69 percent 10 months ago.
item.description: Ahead of voting on Saturday, approval ratings for the leaders of Australia’s two major parties have tumbled, and voters seem to be drawn to the fringes.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: In Trade Stances Toward China, Clinton and Trump Both Signal a Chill
item.media:description: A container ship tied up at a Chinese-financed port in Sri Lanka. Millions of jobs in China and across the region rely on the willingness of the United States to buy imports from China.
item.description: The candidates, grappling with economic populism and increasing concern over China’s military posture, could follow through on campaign pledges to toughen trade policy.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: E.U. Leaders Chart Future as David Cameron Leaves Brussels
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany arrived in Brussels on Wednesday, before a European Union summit meeting.
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Reeling from Britain’s vote to quit, they agreed the European Union must change, but nothing was decided except to hold another meeting in the fall.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Obama, Justin Trudeau and Enrique Peña Nieto Focus on Climate, Both Political and Global
item.description: The three North American leaders met in Ottawa, focusing on climate change and the ripples from Britain’s vote, and disavowed nativist political currents.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Lu Wei, China’s Internet Czar, Will Step Down From Post
item.media:description: From left, Lu Wei, the gatekeeper of China’s internet; Xi Jinping, China’s president; and Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Facebook, during a meeting last year at Microsoft’s main campus in Redmond, Washington.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ted S. Warren
item.description: Given the opacity of the Chinese government, it was not clear whether Mr. Lu was in trouble or in line for a promotion.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Maiduguri Journal: From Boko Haram’s Birthplace, Instagram Posts Beyond ‘Death and Despair’
item.media:description: The photographer Fati Abubakar, 30, documents the people of Maiduguri, Nigeria, determined to show the world that life continues despite years of violence that has killed thousands of people, many within the city limits.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: A woman in violence-plagued Maiduguri, Nigeria, has developed a following by capturing residents’ positive stories on Instagram — though they can be hard to come by.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Tibetan Director Hospitalized After Detention by Chinese Police
item.media:description: The director Pema Tseden at a film festival in Switzerland in 2009.
item.description: During his detention, Pema Tseden “displayed health problems” that required hospitalization, the Film Directors Guild of China said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: David Cameron Leaves Brussels Early; Conservatives Seek New Leader
item.media:description: Dalia Grybauskaite, the president of Lithuania, was among leaders in Brussels on Wednesday who expressed alarm about Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
item.description: The British prime minister was excluded from European Union meetings, and Britain’s two main parties are both grappling with leadership changes.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO

item.title: What in the World: In China, Cheese Is Strange, but Pizza Is Hot
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin / Love_Life / Boarding1Now / iStock.com
item.description: Dairy is not part of the mainstream Chinese diet, but one cheese seller’s prospects may improve as fast food, especially pizza, catches on.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: France’s Latest American Import: Mermaid Schools
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; Photos by Jung Hsuan, Valentyna Chukhlyebova/shutterstock
item.description: How would it feel to be Ariel from Disney’s “The Little Mermaid”? Girls who share that fantasy — and some women — are pulling on monofins and finding out.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: What in the World: It’s Dogs vs. Poachers in the Fight to Protect Elephants
item.media:credit: Illustration by Leif Parsons; Photo by Jagodka/Shutterstock
item.description: Tanzania has trained four Belgian Malinois to check cargo and luggage for smuggled ivory at the main airport and port in Dar es Salaam.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Erdogan in His Labyrinth
item.description: Turkey's descent into violence is of Erdogan's own creation. The airport attack was in many ways a bloodbath foretold.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Summer Camp Under Siege
item.media:description: Palestinian children play in the Jabalia refugee camp in the Gaza Strip.
item.description: Children in Gaza have little enough to look forward to. Now their holiday fun is under threat.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED OMER
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Syria, Starving Instead of Fasting
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have spent Ramadan under siege while the world does nothing.
item.dc:creator: AVI ASHER-SCHAPIRO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
